This chunk is part of a comprehensive guide detailing various methods for manipulating sounds in a programming environment. Specifically, it focuses on techniques for looping sounds, including enabling and disabling loops, setting loop counts, and addressing common issues related to seamless sound looping. The section provides code examples in both Python and C++, making it useful for developers working with different languages. It also includes important notes about potential pitfalls, such as issues with certain file formats or sound systems, which are crucial for ensuring smooth audio playback in applications.

Manipulating Sounds

Looping a Sound

To cause a sound to loop (i.e., cause it to repeat once it is finished playing) do the following:

python

mySound.setLoop(True)
mySound.play()

cpp

mySound->set_loop(true);
mySound->play();

To stop a sound from looping pass False in the ~.AudioSound.set_loop() function.

python

mySound.setLoop(False)

cpp

mySound->set_loop(false);

Sounds can also be looped for a certain number of times:

python

mySound.setLoopCount(n)

cpp

mySound->set_loop_count(n);

Where 'n' can be any positive integer. 0 will cause a sound to loop forever. 1 will cause a sound to play only once. >1 will cause a sound to loop that many times.

Note

Setting a sound's loop count to 0 or >1 will automatically set a sound's loop flag to true.
